TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr J. Buzalka , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the former ORG ( místní národní výbor ) assigned a CARDINAL - room flat to PERSON and his wife , PERSON , in a ORG owned apartment house .

On DATE ORG ( bytový podnik ) brought proceedings against PERSON and a certain Ms Z before the Prague CARDINAL ORG ( obvodní soud ) asking that their tenancy be terminated and that PERSON and Ms Z be ordered to leave the flat . It alleged that the tenants had failed to pay the rent for DATE .

By a judgment of DATE , ORG terminated the tenancy of PERSON and Ms Z , and ordered them to leave the flat within DATE of the allocation of a substitute flat by the competent national council . The judgment was served on the parties at DATE . On DATE it became final .
On DATE Mr X commenced divorce proceedings against Ms Y. The judgment declaring the divorce was notified to the latter at her new address in DATE . The judgment of DATE was served on her in DATE .
In DATE the applicant became the owner of the apartment .

On DATE he introduced a civil action in ORG , seeking a declaration that the eviction of PERSON should not be conditional on the allocation of alternative accommodation . The applicant claimed that the former tenant had not paid the rent and maintenance contributions for DATE . He submitted that the flat had been assigned to PERSON and his wife , PERSON , on DATE and that after their divorce , PERSON had been provided with a substitute flat , PERSON having continued to occupy the common flat . The applicant further submitted that ORG had terminated the tenancy of PERSON and his wife , and had ordered them to leave the flat within DATE of the allocation of a substitute flat by the competent national council .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s action finding , inter alia , that the fact that PERSON owed rent for DATE , or that he had caused disorder in the house , did not substantiate the applicant ’s argument that the circumstances , on which the original judgment of CARDINAL DATE had been based , had changed , thereby justifying its modification .

On DATE ORG ( městský soud ) quashed the first instance judgment , finding that the former tenant ’s continued unlawful behaviour , which had constituted the reason for the termination of the tenancy , had to be considered as an alteration of the circumstances ( změna poměrů ) on which ORG had originally based its judgment of DATE . It ordered ORG to clarify the circumstances in which PERSON had defaulted on the payment of his rent .

On DATE ORG again dismissed the applicant ’s action on the ground that the applicant had not proved that PERSON had violated his tenancy obligations . It further held that the amount of rent which the applicant had asked PERSON to pay was contrary to the national law .

On DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment applying , inter alia , section III(CARDINAL ) of Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL which amended LAW . The court modified , however , the reasons for the decision . It held that the judgment of DATE had not become final and could not , therefore , be modified upon the applicant ’s request . It found that the eviction order had not been directed against the same persons , to whom the flat had originally been allocated in DATE . It further found that Ms Y had not been a party to the DATE proceedings , and the fact that the DATE judgment had been notified to her in DATE was irrelevant .

On DATE ORG ( Vrchní soud ) dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on points of law ( dovolání ) . The court , considering that the judgment of ORG was a decision which had modified the first instance judgment , applied section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) and section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) of the Code of Civil Procedure ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” , below ) . It shared ORG opinion that , if the original decision ordering the tenant ’s eviction upon the allocation of a substitute flat had not become final , the applicant could not evict him without alternative accommodation being provided . The court added that the relevant judgment had clearly referred to Ms Z and not PERSON , and that this had not been rectified , at least under LAW CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure .

On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) dismissed as being manifestly ill - founded the applicant ’s constitutional appeal ( ústavní stížnost ) , in which the applicant had alleged a violation of Articles QUANTITY and LAW základních práv a svobod ) , as well as LAW .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) provides that a judgment , which has been duly served and which can no longer be appealed , becomes final . Once a case has been adjudicated and the decision has become final , it may not be reconsidered .
Pursuant to section CARDINAL ) , the president of a chamber may rectify anytime and , if necessary ex officio , clerical errors or any other evident incorrectness in a judgment .
Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) , an appeal on points of law is admissible against a judgment of an appellate court , whereby the first instance judgment was modified .
Pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) , an appeal on points of law may be filed on the ground that a decision was based on the incorrect legal consideration of the matter .

Section III , containing the concluding and interim provisions , provides in its sixth sub - section that final judgments ordering an eviction from an apartment which were adopted before the entry into force of this LAW , and which made the eviction conditional on the allocation of a substitute flat or other accommodation , retain their conditional nature . The beneficiary may nevertheless request a court , which is competent to execute the judgment , to modify that order and declare that the party leaving the flat should only be provided with substitute accommodation rather than a flat , or that no alternative housing need be allocated at all .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that everyone may assert his or her rights before an independent and impartial court of justice or , in specified cases , before another authority .

Under LAW , everyone is entitled to have his or her case considered in public without unnecessary delay , in his or her presence , and to express his or her opinion on all the submitted evidence . The public may be excluded only in those cases specified by law .
